intro: Aesculus glabra var. monticola, commonly known as the Appalachian buckeye, is a deciduous tree native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Sapindaceae family and is characterized by its palmately compound leaves with five to seven leaflets. The tree produces showy, yellowish-green flowers in upright clusters, followed by spiny, woody fruits containing one or two seeds. Its bark is smooth and grayish-brown, often with shallow fissures, and it can grow up to 20 meters tall in suitable conditions. The plant is adapted to a variety of soil types but prefers well-drained, moist soils in full sun to partial shade.
